_header: No more of this for Gods dignity
Title(s): ‘Thopas-Melibee Link’; ‘Words of the Host to Chaucer’; Canterbury Tales
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the ‘Thopas-Melibee Link’ in the Canterbury Tales — 48 lines in rhyming couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
NO more of this for godis dignitequod oure Oste for thow makest
                    me…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…and therfore herkeneth what I shal sayeand lete me telle al
                    my tale I pray
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
Here oure Ost letteth Chauncers his rymyng (f. 170v); Mellibe
                    (RT); Here bigineth Chauncers another tale off / Mellibe and Prudence &
                    Sophia Chauncers Tale (f. 171; prose tale follows Thopas)

BodBar20.First Lines:
NOmore of þis for goddes digniteQuod oure Oste for þou
                    makest me…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…And herkene what I shal sayeAnd let me telle my tale I
                    praie
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
here endith Chauncers prolog and / here begynnyth þe tale of Mellebe
                    (f. 206v; prose tale follows Thopas)

Bod414.First Lines:
No more of this for goddis digniteCoth oure host for thou makist
                    me…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkneth what that I seyAnd let me telle alle my
                    tale I you prayHere endith Chaucers tale of Sir ThopasA doughty knyght
                    in all his dedeGod help us alle and seint ThomasAnd graunt us his
                    grace wele to spede Amen
Bod414.Note: Four spurious lines follow VII.966 (see above).
Bod414.Attributed Title:
The tale of Melibeus and prudence (f. 151, prose tale following
                        Thopas)

Bod686.First Lines:
Namore of þis for goddes digniteQuod oure host for þou
                    makest me…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…After þe whiche þis myry tale y writeAnd
                    þerfore herkeneth what y shal you seyAnd lete me tellen as my tale y
                    prey
Bod686.Note:
Two spurious lines follow precede VII.966 introducing
                        Manciple’s Tale, which follows in this MS.
Bod686.Attributed Title:
Here the hoost stynteth Chaucer of his tale of / Thopas And biddeth hym
                    telle a nother tale (f. 172v); Here endeth Chaucers tale… (f.
                        173v)

BodHatDon1.First Lines:
No more of þis for goddis digniteQuod oure ooste for thou
                    makist me…
BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…And therefore herkeneth what I shal seyAnd late me tell al my
                    tale I pray
BodHatDon1.Attributed Title:
…And next biginneth the / Prolog of Chaucer (f. 189v); The
                    Chaucer of Melibeus (RT); Here endeth the Prolog of the Chauncers And next
                    biginneth / the tale of the Chauncer (f. 190; prose tale follows
                    Thopas)

BodLauMis600.First Lines:
No more of þis for goddes digniteQuod oure host for þou
                    makest me…
BodLauMis600.Last Lines:
…And þerfor herkeneþ what I shal saiAnd let me telle
                    al my tale I pray
BodLauMis600.Attributed Title:
Oure host (f. 228); Narracio (f. 228v; prose tale follows
                        Thopas)

BodRawPoe141.First Lines:
NO more of this for godes dignyteQuod oure ost for thou makest
                    me…
BodRawPoe141.Last Lines:
…Ther fore herkeneth what I shall seyAnd let me telle my tale
                    I prey
BodRawPoe141.Attributed Title:
The rehercyng of oure ost (f. 97); Chaucer (RT); Here begynneth chaucers
                    tale of Melebe & Prudence (f. 98; prose tale follows
                    Thopas)

BodRawPoe149.First Lines:
NO more of this for godes digniteQuod oure oste for thou makist
                    me…
BodRawPoe149.Last Lines:
…And herkenith what I shal sayAnd late me tele my tale I
                    prey
BodRawPoe149.Attributed Title:
…and / here begynneth Melibes prolog (f. 105v); melibe (f.
                        105v, margin); Mellibe (RT); Mellibe (f. 106, margin); here
                    begynneth Mellibes tale (f. 106; prose tale follows Thopas)

BodRawPoe223.First Lines:
Nomore of this for goddis digniteQuod oure oost for thou makest
                    me…
BodRawPoe223.Last Lines:
…And herkeneth what that I shall sayAnd late me telle my tale
                    I pray
BodRawPoe223.Attributed Title:
Chaucer (RT); Here endith the tale of Maister Chaucer / And here ye shuyl
                    fynde a moral tale of Melibe and Prudence (f. 183; prose tale follows
                        Thopas)

OxfChrCh152.First Lines:
No more of this for goddys digniteQuod oure hoost for thow makest
                    me…
OxfChrCh152.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkeneth what that I shall seyeAnd late me
                    tellen al my tale I preye
OxfChrCh152.Attributed Title:
Here endeth chaucers tale of Thopas / And begynneth his tale of Melibeus
                    (f. 138v; prose tale follows Thopas)

OxfCCC198.First Lines:
NOmore of þis for goddes digniteQuoþ oure hoste for
                    þou makest me…
OxfCCC198.Last Lines:
…And herkene what I schal seyeAnd let me telle my tale I
                    ȝou preye
OxfCCC198.Facsimiles:
“Digital
                    Facsimile of Corpus Christi, Oxford MS 198 of the Canterbury
            Tales”  .

OxfNew314.First Lines:
NO more quod our ost for goddis digniteffor thou so weri makist
                    me…
OxfNew314.Last Lines:
…And þerfor harkenyth what I shal sayAnd let me telle my
                    tale I you pray
OxfNew314.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth Chauceris tale (f. 237; prose tale of Melibee follows
                        Thopas)

OxfTri49.First Lines:
No more of this for goddis dignitequoth oure hoste for thou makist
                    me…
OxfTri49.Last Lines:
…and ther for herkenyth what I shal sayand late me tellyn my
                    tale I pray
OxfTri49.Attributed Title:
Incipit fabula Chauceris (f. 201v; prose tale follows
                        Thopas)

CULDd424.First Lines:
Nomore of this for goddes dignyteeQuod oure hoost for thow makest
                    meSo wery of thyn verray lewednesse…
CULDd424.Last Lines:
…And þerfore herkeneth what that I shal seyeAnd lat me
                    tellen al my tale I preye
CULDd424.Attributed Title:
Here endeth Chaucers tale of Thopas / & the Prologe of Melibeus / And
                    heere bigynneth the Tale of Melibeus (f. 160v; prose tale follows
                        Thopas)

CULIi326.First Lines:
NO more of this for goddis digniteQuod oure hoste for thou makest
                    me…
CULIi326.Last Lines:
…And herkenyth what I shall sayAnd lete me telle all my tale I
                    you prey
CULIi326.Attributed Title:
Chawcers (RT); Here endeth the prologe of chawcers / And here begynneth his
                    tale of Mellebeus and dame / Prudence And Sophia her doughter (f. 189; prose
                    tale follows Thopas)

CULMm25.First Lines:
No more of þis for goddis digniteQuod oure ooste for you
                    makest me…
CULMm25.Last Lines:
…And þer for herkeneth what I schall seyeAnd lat me tell
                    all my tale I praye

CamFitzMc181.First Lines:
No more of this for goddes dignyteeQuoth oure oste for þou
                    makest me…
CamFitzMc181.Last Lines:
…I prey yow blameth not for as in my sentenceYe
                    schull fynde no dyfference
CamFitzMc181.Attributed Title:
The prolog of Mellibe (f. 220); Here endeth þe Prolog of Chaucers (f.
                        220v); Chausers Tale of (f. 221; the prose tale of Melibee
                    follows Thopas)

CamTCC582.First Lines:
Nomore of this for goddes digniteQuod oure oost for thou makist
                    me…
CamTCC582.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkeneth what I shal sayAnd lat me telle all my
                    tale I prayWich anon in prose I wol telle in this presenceOf Melibe
                    and his wif and there douȝter Sapience
CamTCC582.Note:
VII.925 omitted; spurious lines follow 926, 966 (for the latter see
                    above).
CamTCC582.Attributed Title:
Verba hospitis (f. 87va); Anothir tale in prose / tolde
                    be master Chaucer / of Melibe and Prudence (f. 87vb; prose tale
                    follows Thopas)

BLAdd5140.First Lines:
No more of this for goddis dignyteQuod oure host for thou makest
                    be…
BLAdd5140.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkenyth what that I shal seyeAnd lete me telle
                    al my tale I preye
BLAdd5140.Attributed Title:
Chauncer (RT); Hic incipit narracio Galfridi / Chauncere de Mellibeo
                    (f. 239; the prose Melibee follows Thopas)

BLAdd35286.First Lines:
Na more of this for goddes digniteQuod our host for thow makest
                    me…
BLAdd35286.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkeneth what that I shal seyeAnd lat me tellen
                    al my tale I preye
BLAdd35286.Attributed Title:
Here bigynneth a reheytyng of our hoost (f. 168); Chaucer (RT); Here
                    bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibee and Prudence (f. 168v; the prose
                        Melibee follows Thopas)

BLEge2726.First Lines:
No more of this for goddes dignyteeKoth oure host for þou
                    makest me…
BLEge2726.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkeneth what þat I preyAnd let me tell
                    all my tale I prey
BLEge2726.Attributed Title:
Hic desinit fabula de Sir Thopas & / Incipit fabula de Melibeus
                    (f. 182v; the prose Melibee follows Thopas)

BLLan851.First Lines:
NO mor of þis for goddis dignitequod oure ost foure þou
                    makest me…
BLLan851.Last Lines:
…And Herken whatt I schal seyeAnd lett me tale I
                    preye

PhilRos10842.Transcription:
No more of this for goddis digniteQuod our hoost for þow makist
                    meSo wery of thy lewdnesThat also wisly God my soule
                    blis…
PhilRos10842.Note:
An 11-folio fragment, of which this leaf bears VII.846-918 of
                        Thopas and 919-22 the ‘Thopas-Melibee Link’.

BNangl39.First Lines:
Nomore of this for goddis dignytequoth oure host for thou makist
                    me…
BNangl39.Last Lines:
…and therfore herkyneth what I shal seyand lat me telle al my
                    tale I prey
BNangl39.Attributed Title:
Verba hospitis ad Chauncers (f. 71vb); Hic narrat
                        fabulam suam Galfri / dus Chauncers de quodam Iuuene vocato Mellebeus
                    (f. 72ra). Only this incipit for the prose Melibee is
                    present in this MS; the Tale is omitted, leaving most of the recto and
                    verso of f. 72 blank.

TokyoTak32.First Lines:
Namoore of this for goddis dingiteeQuod owre Ooste for thow makist
                    mee…
TokyoTak32.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkenyht what I seyeAnd late mee tellen my tale
                    I yow preyehere Endyht Chauceris tale of sire thopasA dowghty
                    knyght in alle his dedeGod vs helpe and seint ThomasAnd graunt vs alle
                    grace weel to spede
TokyoTak32.Note:
Four spurious lines follow VII.966, in turn followed by 18 blank lines
                    (the rest of the verso).
TokyoTak32.Attributed Title:
Chauceris tale (RT); [tear]yht Giffrey Caseris tale of Mellibe and Prudence
                    (f. 108; the prose Melibee follows Thopas)
